Certainly! Here are some examples of recent works of literature that challenge traditional gender roles and offer alternative perspectives:

1. "Red, White & Royal Blue" by Casey McQuiston - This novel features the romantic relationship between the son of the US president and the Prince of Wales, challenging traditional portrayals of masculinity and heteronormative relationships.

2. "The Girl with the Louding Voice" by Abi Daré - This novel follows a Nigerian girl who dreams of getting an education and escaping her abusive home life, subverting traditional gender roles that limit girls' education and opportunities.

3. "The City We Became" by N.K. Jemisin - This novel features a diverse cast of characters of different genders, races, and sexualities fighting to save New York City from an interdimensional threat, offering a fresh perspective on heroism and leadership.

4. "The Water Cure" by Sophie Mackintosh - This novel explores a dystopian society in which men are portrayed as the weaker and more vulnerable sex, subverting the traditional gender roles in patriarchal societies.

5. "Freshwater" by Akwaeke Emezi - This novel follows a Nigerian woman coming to terms with her gender identity as a young child, ultimately challenging binary gender norms and exploring the complexities of individual identity.

These works are just a few examples of the many recent works of literature that challenge traditional gender roles and offer alternative perspectives. They demonstrate the power of literature to question and subvert societal norms, promoting inclusivity and diversity in representation.
